#Omicron and #variantsofconcern #VOC in vitro phenotypes #SARSCVoV2 #COVID19, work from @gcevd @Hopitaux_unige led by @essaidimanel now out as preprint! https://t.co/3hoBrlMWUj

Quite interesting, there was also this paper published today: Omicron emerged under immune pressure. So for the moment iot seems that high virus circulation under increasing population immunity is driving variants evolvement https://t.co/Vros45N18v

As a plus, we could not see infection in cell liens from European bats, rodents, hedgehog or carnivores, which could indicate that these animals are not risk species for  establishing a new animal reservoir

Thus, we believe our data indicate that Omicron rather presents a better adaptation towards humans than a virus that has evolved going through other species. Of course in vitro studies on cell lines have limitations but for most cell lines used, no animal model is available

We did not see an increased host range of Omicron (or Delta) compared to ancestral SAS-CoV-2 in any of the cell lines, but increasing efficiency to infect a human cell lines from ancestral to Delta to Omicron.

All other VOCs showed comparable patterns but Omicrons phenotype in vitro stands out, most pronounced on cells of he upper airways vs lung cell lines. We also tested replication in 17 cell lines from 11 mammalian species, including bats, rodents, insectivores and carnivores

Here, we studies Omicron BA.1 vs. all other VOCs and ancestral SARS-CoV-2 in human primary upper airway epithelial cells and other lung-derived cell lines. Only Omicron show a very early replication peak after 24 h with early efficient production of infectious virus

Where did Omicron come from? Theories include a circulation in hidden populations, under immune-pressure/chronic infection, or reverse zoonosis. Our pre-print is out, looking at potential extension of host range in animals vs. better human adaptation https://t.co/dY3WZR4cAJ

can be a great way to reduce travel, CO2 emission, reduce time away from home, allow participation for those that cannot travel. Being pregnant & on maternity leave during the pandemic, I have experienced how much more I could stay up-to-date & connected, thanks to hybrid options

Other aspects, not only related to #COVID, also need improvement at scientific conferences, such as child care options, a place to pump & store breast milk for young mothers, financial/organizational support if partner/children accompany the participant - Online participation

We often argue for more inclusion, for more equity, for more diversity (...) in science - taking care of colleagues with risk conditions, offering them to participate in a conference in a safe environment & showing that colleagues & organizers care is an absolut must in my view

Especially in medical specialties, it find it rather embarrassing when conferences are held under conditions that contradict all evidence of good public health practice of the last 2,5 years. Difficult to preach measures/care for risk patients but not taking care at huge events.

countries that still take #SARSCoV2 #COVID19 more seriously than most US/European countries right now, also for countries with less/no access to treatment or with weak health systems. There are still people who never had #COVID19 & have their reasons to keep it like this.

Even if this can only cover the part of the meeting itself & not travel/private meetings outside, such measures can have great impact & show the participants that organizers care: also for those with underlying conditions or with such a household member, for participants from

On the more advanced site, I would love to see conference centers investing in air purifiers, allow their windows to be opened in all rooms, and install CO2-meters to monitor air quality, as well as routinely offer an option for coffee breaks/smaller meetings outside.

with many international guests, a pre-meeting negative test can be a good option too, or additional testing on site, to reduce the number of actively shedding individuals during the meeting. Even if only few are identified, it can have a strong impact on transmission on site.

at least during talks & in crowded rooms, offer enough space to meet outside (coffee break, lunch, dinner, informal get-together, cocktails), offer a hybrid option for those that are sick, etc. - these are easy solutions that can be easily implemented. For very large meetings

With current #SARSCoV2 situation, there won't be a zero-risk meeting, but there are many ways how organizers can prevent a superspreader event: Pay attention to well-ventilated facilities, choose large auditoriums, always keep windows/doors open, recommend masks, also for staff,

Conferences are a great way to meet & it is so good again they are back to presence meetings or at least hybrid. However, conferences bring together participants from all over the world, thus creating an opportunity for mixing of all sorts of currently circulating variants

e.g. global health conference without any measures, business conference (non-medical experts) with rather strict measures. The best & most stringent health concept I've seen so far was a small virology meeting (testing before & during the event, especially before social evening).

The only item that I saw in every meeting was hand disinfectant though (which is a good thing in general but not effective against #SARSCoV2 transmission). Funnily enough there was not necessarily a correlation between topic (expertise) of the conference & stringency of measures,

with the full spectrum from complete ignorance of #SARSCoV2 to really well planned measures to reduce infection risks e.g. some meetings with crowded rooms with poor ventilation & no masks, others requiring vaccination + PCR in advance + on site + strong recommendation for masks

For organizers of conferences in 2022 (and after) having a sanitary concept for #SARSCoV2 #COVID19 must be part of the conference package & I find it very strange when it's not the case, especially in medical/public health/life sciences. I've been to several conferences recently

Public health impact of our findings: vaccination can reduce infectious viral load, likely leading to lower onward transmission. These findings underscore the benefit of #vaccination on #SARSCoV2 circulation beyond individual protection from severe disease #SARSCoV2 #COVID19 8/

Our data demonstrate that 1) measuring viral RNA (Ct values/copy numbers) are not the full story when it comes to viral load 2) it's important to asses infectious (culturable) virus to better understand viral shedding profiles 3) vaccination impacts infectious viral load 7/

Next, effect of #vaccination (2x or 3x) on infectious viral load in #Omicron BA.1 infections: Individuals with 2x mRNA vaccine had comparable infectious viral load to unvaccinated. But with additional (booster) dose we saw a more than 5-fold reduction in infectious viral load! 6/ https://t.co/HbFjSBynSA

For Omicron BA.1 infections, we have investigated infectious viral load for unvaccinated, 2x vaccinated & 3x vaccinated individuals. In 2x vaccinated individuals with a breakthrough infection, Omicron (while being highly contagious) had lower infectious viral load than Delta! 5/ https://t.co/PjEbG6seAn

Next, we have investigated the effect of #vaccination (2 doses mRNA) on infectious viral load: In vaccinated individuals with a Delta breakthrough infection, infectious virus was almost 5-fold lower & was cleared more rapidly than in the unvaccinated with Delta 4/ https://t.co/JcfaRuc1Ao

First of all, we found a rather low correlation between viral RNA copies and infectious viral titers & no correlation of infectious viral load with age or sex. Infectious viral load in unvaccinated individuals was higher when infected with #Delta than with pre-VOC #SARSCoV2 3/ https://t.co/8HhVLKIZTG

We assessed infectious viral particles & RNA viral load from nasopharyngeal swabs of 565 #SARSCoV2 infected individuals in the first 5 days post symptom onset over several waves: 2020 ("pre-VOC", before the rise of #variants of concern), #Delta in 2021 & #Omicron in 2022. 2/

Last, we compared RNA copies & infectious viral titers in Delta & Omicron breakthrough infections & did not find differences in quantity. Although Omicron is highly transmissible even from vaccinated index cases, it does not seem to be due to higher viral loads compared to Delta! https://t.co/n5u2eA0XvO

RNA copies did not differ much between Delta in unvaccinated vs vaccinated individuals, but viral load shedding was much lower (0.68 log) & declined faster in breakthrough. However, half of the vaccine breakthrough samples still had infectious virus at 5 dpos! 5/ https://t.co/TbBfwDYAav

Also, infectious viral load was higher for Delta 3-5 days after symptoms, while similar to per-VOC #SARSCoV2 during first 0-2 days. More & longer infectious virus shedding could explain higher transmissibility of Delta. Next, we looked at Delta vaccine breakthrough infections 4/

Next, we quantified infectious viral particles in early-pandemic #SARSCoV2 (before any variant of concern, "pre-VOC") & #Delta in unvaccinated individuals: we found higher RNA copy numbers in pre-VOC than Delta, but more infectious viral load in Delta 3/ https://t.co/gUanQxrf2x

We found only a low correlation between RNA genome copies & infectious viral titers as determined by focus forming assay for #SARSCoV2 Wt, #Delta infection & Delta vaccine breakthrough - means, RNA viral load does not tell so much about infectiousness 2/

Just to be clear: Both approaches (cultured virus, small set of retrospective samples) are far from perfect, but it is the best we could in such a short time. Also remember that clinical studies are staff-intensive & we need to assess infecting variant for each participant!
Work was a great effort from my team & @BenjaminMeyer85 @Hopitaux_unige @unige_en @MIMOL_UNIGE led by @MBekliz, funded by @snf_ch. Hopefully soon on Medrxiv!

Last point probably most important right now: If you catch Omicron (and you probably will) better do it vaccinated. Reassuring to see really good Delta-neutralization, most likely cross-protective. We lack assessment of primary Omicron-infection here (no samples available yet)

Overall we see previous infection, independent of variant, does not neutralize Omicron well, but differences in variant-specific immunity could influence epidemiology. Better neutralization with 2-dose vaccine but also here a loss. Best immunity is combined infection+vaccine

here only 18-fold loss for Omicron 5) vaccine break-through with Delta showed high titers & robust neutralization for Omicron with only 12.5-fold loss 6) vaccine-break through with Omicron showed robust neutralization for both Delta (only 1.5-fold loss) & Omicron! 5/ https://t.co/4iBeZ6ZtRf

3) best neutralization was always seen against homologous (previously infecting) variant 4) two-dose vaccination showed much higher titers than infection but drop for Omicron was still large with 85-fold. 4) infection followed by 2-dose vaccination protected much better 4/

Our findings: 1) convalescent samples of pre-VOC, Alpha, Beta, Gamma & Delta show significant loss for Omicron but to different degrees (post-Beta: 23-fold, post-Alpha: 56-fold) 2) Zeta had already strong immune escape (28-fold in post Alpha sera) but did not become dominant 3/ https://t.co/KdhBZJyYas

We tested 104 sera/plasma against clinical isolates of early-pandemic #SARSCoV2 (pre-VOC), #Alpha, #Beta, #Gamma, #Delta, #Zeta, #Omicron. Convalescent sera/plasma were from individuals infected with pre-VOC, Alpha, Beta, Gamma or Delta, vaccinees & vaccine break-throughs 2/

Our study on neutralizing titers of 7 authentic #SARSCoV2 isolates (all #variants of concern incl. #Omicron) in a background of variant-specific-, vaccine- & vaccine break-through-immunity is uploaded here: https://t.co/qzb4JVNPEh #COVID19  What did we find? A üßµ 1/n

Limitations of the data shown here: retrospective testing, small sample number, all samples had one freeze-thaw cycle, test was not done at the point of care but with swabs stored in viral transport medium. Key message: Don't use a negative rapid test to abandon other measures!

Note: yes, the studies mentioned above started already with a virus that had 3 mutations inserted & not with the wild type. However, these mutations that make the virus more transmissible in mammals exist already in nature. The current H5N1 outbreak is huge - they may arise too

Yet there is no moratorium, not even much media interest. Minks & ferrets, and many other small carnivores farmed for fur (or meat in some regions) are highly susceptible to influenza & coronaviruses, incl SARS & SARS2. Why on earth, in year 3 of a pandemic, is this still done?

There‚Äôs a lot of media reports on biosafety/biosecurity risks of virus research. I do not want to downplay & yes labs have to operate safely, but the magnitude of risk in farmed wildlife is several orders above any lab research. Not even all of such outbreaks will be detected!

Now, there‚Äôs a H5N1 found in a mink farm. If transmission takes place on a large scale, it comes close to the experiment from above, just outside of a lab, not in a few ferrets in a high security lab, but in 50.000 ferrets, in contact to humans & other animals, incl wildlife

The work back then used ferrets as a model for transmission & was particular interested in viral mutations to allow for airborne spread. Although done in a high security lab, such work was considered an unnecessary risk by many, as it was creating mammal-adapted avian influenza

Do you remember 2012? There was a moratorium on a research project that looked for mutations to make avian #influenza #H5N1 more transmissible in mammals. There was a huge public outcry that such work should not be done https://t.co/mafWsax6bn

As a plus, we could not see infection in cell liens from European bats, rodents, hedgehog or carnivores, which could indicate that these animals are not risk species for  establishing a new animal reservoir

Thus, we believe our data indicate that Omicron rather presents a better adaptation towards humans than a virus that has evolved going through other species. Of course in vitro studies on cell lines have limitations but for most cell lines used, no animal model is available

We did not see an increased host range of Omicron (or Delta) compared to ancestral SAS-CoV-2 in any of the cell lines, but increasing efficiency to infect a human cell lines from ancestral to Delta to Omicron.

All other VOCs showed comparable patterns but Omicrons phenotype in vitro stands out, most pronounced on cells of he upper airways vs lung cell lines. We also tested replication in 17 cell lines from 11 mammalian species, including bats, rodents, insectivores and carnivores

Here, we studies Omicron BA.1 vs. all other VOCs and ancestral SARS-CoV-2 in human primary upper airway epithelial cells and other lung-derived cell lines. Only Omicron show a very early replication peak after 24 h with early efficient production of infectious virus

Where did Omicron come from? Theories include a circulation in hidden populations, under immune-pressure/chronic infection, or reverse zoonosis. Our pre-print is out, looking at potential extension of host range in animals vs. better human adaptation https://t.co/dY3WZR4cAJ

can be a great way to reduce travel, CO2 emission, reduce time away from home, allow participation for those that cannot travel. Being pregnant & on maternity leave during the pandemic, I have experienced how much more I could stay up-to-date & connected, thanks to hybrid options

Other aspects, not only related to #COVID, also need improvement at scientific conferences, such as child care options, a place to pump & store breast milk for young mothers, financial/organizational support if partner/children accompany the participant - Online participation

We often argue for more inclusion, for more equity, for more diversity (...) in science - taking care of colleagues with risk conditions, offering them to participate in a conference in a safe environment & showing that colleagues & organizers care is an absolut must in my view

Especially in medical specialties, it find it rather embarrassing when conferences are held under conditions that contradict all evidence of good public health practice of the last 2,5 years. Difficult to preach measures/care for risk patients but not taking care at huge events.

countries that still take #SARSCoV2 #COVID19 more seriously than most US/European countries right now, also for countries with less/no access to treatment or with weak health systems. There are still people who never had #COVID19 & have their reasons to keep it like this.

Even if this can only cover the part of the meeting itself & not travel/private meetings outside, such measures can have great impact & show the participants that organizers care: also for those with underlying conditions or with such a household member, for participants from

On the more advanced site, I would love to see conference centers investing in air purifiers, allow their windows to be opened in all rooms, and install CO2-meters to monitor air quality, as well as routinely offer an option for coffee breaks/smaller meetings outside.

with many international guests, a pre-meeting negative test can be a good option too, or additional testing on site, to reduce the number of actively shedding individuals during the meeting. Even if only few are identified, it can have a strong impact on transmission on site.

at least during talks & in crowded rooms, offer enough space to meet outside (coffee break, lunch, dinner, informal get-together, cocktails), offer a hybrid option for those that are sick, etc. - these are easy solutions that can be easily implemented. For very large meetings

With current #SARSCoV2 situation, there won't be a zero-risk meeting, but there are many ways how organizers can prevent a superspreader event: Pay attention to well-ventilated facilities, choose large auditoriums, always keep windows/doors open, recommend masks, also for staff,

Conferences are a great way to meet & it is so good again they are back to presence meetings or at least hybrid. However, conferences bring together participants from all over the world, thus creating an opportunity for mixing of all sorts of currently circulating variants

e.g. global health conference without any measures, business conference (non-medical experts) with rather strict measures. The best & most stringent health concept I've seen so far was a small virology meeting (testing before & during the event, especially before social evening).

The only item that I saw in every meeting was hand disinfectant though (which is a good thing in general but not effective against #SARSCoV2 transmission). Funnily enough there was not necessarily a correlation between topic (expertise) of the conference & stringency of measures,

with the full spectrum from complete ignorance of #SARSCoV2 to really well planned measures to reduce infection risks e.g. some meetings with crowded rooms with poor ventilation & no masks, others requiring vaccination + PCR in advance + on site + strong recommendation for masks

For organizers of conferences in 2022 (and after) having a sanitary concept for #SARSCoV2 #COVID19 must be part of the conference package & I find it very strange when it's not the case, especially in medical/public health/life sciences. I've been to several conferences recently

Last, we compared RNA copies & infectious viral titers in Delta & Omicron breakthrough infections & did not find differences in quantity. Although Omicron is highly transmissible even from vaccinated index cases, it does not seem to be due to higher viral loads compared to Delta! https://t.co/n5u2eA0XvO

RNA copies did not differ much between Delta in unvaccinated vs vaccinated individuals, but viral load shedding was much lower (0.68 log) & declined faster in breakthrough. However, half of the vaccine breakthrough samples still had infectious virus at 5 dpos! 5/ https://t.co/TbBfwDYAav

Also, infectious viral load was higher for Delta 3-5 days after symptoms, while similar to per-VOC #SARSCoV2 during first 0-2 days. More & longer infectious virus shedding could explain higher transmissibility of Delta. Next, we looked at Delta vaccine breakthrough infections 4/

Next, we quantified infectious viral particles in early-pandemic #SARSCoV2 (before any variant of concern, "pre-VOC") & #Delta in unvaccinated individuals: we found higher RNA copy numbers in pre-VOC than Delta, but more infectious viral load in Delta 3/ https://t.co/gUanQxrf2x

We found only a low correlation between RNA genome copies & infectious viral titers as determined by focus forming assay for #SARSCoV2 Wt, #Delta infection & Delta vaccine breakthrough - means, RNA viral load does not tell so much about infectiousness 2/

Last point probably most important right now: If you catch Omicron (and you probably will) better do it vaccinated. Reassuring to see really good Delta-neutralization, most likely cross-protective. We lack assessment of primary Omicron-infection here (no samples available yet)

Overall we see previous infection, independent of variant, does not neutralize Omicron well, but differences in variant-specific immunity could influence epidemiology. Better neutralization with 2-dose vaccine but also here a loss. Best immunity is combined infection+vaccine

here only 18-fold loss for Omicron 5) vaccine break-through with Delta showed high titers & robust neutralization for Omicron with only 12.5-fold loss 6) vaccine-break through with Omicron showed robust neutralization for both Delta (only 1.5-fold loss) & Omicron! 5/ https://t.co/4iBeZ6ZtRf

3) best neutralization was always seen against homologous (previously infecting) variant 4) two-dose vaccination showed much higher titers than infection but drop for Omicron was still large with 85-fold. 4) infection followed by 2-dose vaccination protected much better 4/

Our findings: 1) convalescent samples of pre-VOC, Alpha, Beta, Gamma & Delta show significant loss for Omicron but to different degrees (post-Beta: 23-fold, post-Alpha: 56-fold) 2) Zeta had already strong immune escape (28-fold in post Alpha sera) but did not become dominant 3/ https://t.co/KdhBZJyYas
